Introduction

Scarlet fever is characterized by a fine, erythematous, papular (sandpaper) rash that occurs in patients infected with group A Streptococcus.  Scarlet fever is most commonly associated with streptococcal pharyngitis, but it can develop following other group A streptococcal infections (eg, after a wound infection or burn).

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Certain strains of Streptococcus pyogenes produce pyrogenic exotoxins that cause delayed-type skin reactivity, resulting in vasodilation and increased capillary permeability.  This leads to the characteristic scarlet fever rash.  Transmission typically occurs through saliva or nasal secretions.  Therefore, risk factors for scarlet fever include the following:



  • Close contact with individuals infected with pyrogenic exotoxinâ€“producing S pyogenes, particularly in crowded environments (eg, schools, day care centers)
  • Poor hygiene practices (eg, sharing beverages or toothbrushes, improper food handling)

Clinical presentation



Scarlet fever mostly occurs in children age 5-12.  Patients typically develop fever, sore throat, and malaise 1-2 days before the rash (

figure 1
).  A fine, erythematous, papular (sandpaper) rash starts in the axillae or groin and spreads to the trunk and extremities (
image 1
).  The papules may coalesce in a linear pattern in the antecubital fossae and axillary folds, known as Pastia lines.  If the cheeks are affected, the skin around the mouth appears pale in comparison, giving the appearance of circumoral pallor (
image 2
).  The rash usually persists for about a week.  As the illness resolves, the rash typically desquamates, causing the skin to peel.



Other clinical findings include pharyngeal erythema with tonsillar exudates, palatal petechiae, strawberry tongue (swollen, bumpy tongue) (

image 3
), headache, nausea, vomiting, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis



Scarlet fever is primarily a clinical diagnosis; a thorough history and physical examination show the characteristic rash and other clinical findings.  Rapid streptococcal antigen testing or throat culture can confirm the presence of S pyogenes.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for scarlet fever is broad and includes:



  • Roseola:  characterized by high fever, which may exceed 40 C (104 F), in infants and young children, followed by a morbilliform rash (
    image 4
    ) on the trunk and extremities.  The rash typically erupts after defervescence.
  • Kawasaki disease:  features 5 days of fever, as well as 4 or more of the following:  polymorphous rash, >1.5 cm cervical node, edema of the hands/feet, nonexudative conjunctivitis, and/or mucosal changes (eg, strawberry tongue, dry/cracked lips).
  • Erythema infectiosum:  a manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection that causes a bright, erythematous rash on the cheeks (ie, slapped-cheek rash).
  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease:  caused by coxsackievirus infection; it presents with lesions on the hands (
    image 5
    ) and feet, including the palms and soles, and oral ulcerations.
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:  exfoliative strains of Staphylococcus aureus that cause superficial flaccid bullae followed by extensive exfoliation of the skin (
    image 6
    ).

Management



Management of scarlet fever involves antibiotic therapy to eradicate S pyogenes and to prevent recurrence and complications (eg, rheumatic fever).  Penicillin V or amoxicillin is preferred; however, cephalosporins, clindamycin, or macrolides may be prescribed in patients with penicillin allergies.  Supportive care with adequate hydration, rest, and analgesics is also important.  Topical emollients may be applied to soothe the skin.  Patients should be monitored closely for resolution of symptoms and complications.

Prognosis



With appropriate antibiotic therapy, the prognosis for scarlet fever is favorable.  Rare complications include rheumatic fever, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, and peritonsillar abscess.

Summary



Scarlet fever (
